Agree, Please go back to the first snapshot, they were perfect!!
Yes please change it back, I know reverting changes is not something Mojang likes, but please just change it back

I would say the crafter change is all OK and reasonable but for goodness sake the change to the copper bulb didn't benefit anyone in any way. I see this as comletely unnecessary. Please revert the copper bulb delay back to 1 game tick, it was only better that way.
Please!!! These changes are completely unacceptable.
Great idea! I was thinking the same thing.
Incredible! Why isn't it already in Minecraft?!
I always felt like it was missing the walls.
Especially since copper is supposed to be a building block... there needs to be more block variation!
We need this for support beams and street lights!
I like!  There could also be a new music disc called "Stalacpipe" .
The stalacpipe has this eerie kind of vibe so it would be awsome to hear some of those sounds if you are in the dripstone caves.
Wonderful idea! I have seen the stalacpipe organ, and its really cool! I think this post should be in "sounds", though; that's where all the other note block instrument ideas were.
Yeah
Mod
This just makes sense. Why wouldn't this make sense?

It depends, if it's grounded to should work like Faraday cage (Google it).

If it was real life, there's high chance that lightning would hit you before going through, because lightning travels through shortest, and easiest road to the ground (it's easier for lightning to travel through human body, than air).
The same should happen with water.

I generally agree, with one caveat: Only damage dealt to entities (This includes the conversion effects of creepers and mooshrooms!) should spread, not fires. Otherwise, building with copper and wood together would become nearly impossible.
Make a minigame to jump up when lightning hits coper blocks? could be fun?
This should be a thing. If mobs or player is sitting on the copper the damage travels to them.
Rip copper roof builders during a thunderstorm

Alternative. Have it spread through lightning rods specifically. Some builds use a variety of copper blocks, and if lightning spread through them, they would all lose their oxidization. And for builders, that's just heartbreaking.

Having it only spread through rods makes it more controllable for redstone too. Imagine a villager based witch farm with a line of rods connecting layers.
Maybe the range of spread should limit to 15 blocks.
The copper bulb delay needs to be reverted back from two ticks to one tick...
I also want it back to normal were the copper bulb is at one game tick and the auto crafter at what ever it was because now they are too slow and the copper bulb lost its most imprtant function
Yeah the new copper bulb changes are awful!

Yes I second this change, eventough I do not approve of your rudeness. I believe the changes to the copper bulb make it less unique and it should be changed back. For the Crafter I think it should get a 2 tick delay instead of a 4 tick delay and not a 1 tick delay in order to avoid lags.
can a datapack or mod do that?
Yes, because it's too ennoying

I genuinely don't understand how this oversight was made by the team.

I've been making an adventure map for over a year now, almost completely finished it, been working hard the past few weeks...

Just to find now that the dialogue prompts that you click on in chat to choose your response or continue the story are completely unusable now.

Nobody is going to want to click yes every time they have to do that.

Come onnn guys.

Seriously, I'm making a server and interactive books are a huge part of it. Having to click a pop-up to confirm something that is supposed to make the process of initiating the command *faster* is just plain stupid.

This being "for security" is not a valid reason. We've been fine without it for the past 16 years why do I need to do an in-game captcha to run a command all of a sudden??
Please! So many adventure maps are ruined by this extra prompt! Have mercy! You have turned thousands of hours of my work into nothing because with this prompt, my maps are unplayable!
All my command books got messed up because of this feature. Mojang, PLEASE

Wenn das nicht auszuschalten ist, werde ich wohl immer auf 1.21.5 bleiben müssen. Ich habe Minecraft seit 11 Jahren. Jetzt bin ich frustriert

If I can't turn this off, I'll probably have to stay on 1.21.5 forever. I've had Minecraft for 11 years. Now I'm frustrated.

Hey, I've been working on an adventure map for about 4 years now with an NPC dialogue mechanic utilizing this feature. This really throws a wrench in the immersion and convenience of command input in the game by the player. 
If we could reconsider this and potentially make it toggleable at the very least, that would be absolutely beneficial to many other map developers everywhere. Thank you.
ill quit the game if they dont fix this

As a mapmaker, it's annoying that anytime I want to run a command in a certain way (clickable chat message, dialog, sign, etc.), players will be prompted with a confirmation box. This is going to be confusing for a lot of players, adding another layer of friction to an interaction.

There's an easy workaround by moving the command you want to run to a ticking function and replacing the original command with a /trigger command. The original command then runs when it detects that the trigger command was run. This makes it useless as a safety feature, as anybody who wants to run commands maliciously can just do this to avoid it.

So what's the problem if there's an easy workaround? The biggest problem is that it adds unnecessary ticking (a small performance hit) and it makes data pack organization a little bit more annoying. Instead of being able to see the command immediately, you have to look in a separate file and reference the scoreboard value that your trigger command sets.

The warning itself is also not particularly useful. Any command can be obfuscated by putting it into a function. Instead of seeing the actual command, players will just see "/function foo:bar". Beyond that, it's clear the warning was added to prevent malicious use of commands, but anybody with bad intentions has dozens of other options, so adding a warning to one method isn't going to stop anybody.

Overall, the feature is annoying for mapmakers, unhelpful for players, and ineffective at stopping bad actors.
yup this broke my command books as well
Thought this was an oversight at first but the fact that this hasn't been fixed for months is ridiculous.
Since dialogs are often used in custom content maps or servers, this screen is USELESS.

I agree, my main concern is obtaining mending books, I have not once in all my years of playing seen a single mending book in a structure. All the mending books I've ever gotten have been from a villager that I've spent several hours rerolling.

Prior to this, looting books and getting them on the enchantment table didn't make sense due to the easy acquisition from librarians through farming and trading.
If you want to return everything as it was, then I am against it. Are not those people who demanded the old PVP with LMB spam voting for this post?

I STRONGLY DISAGREE.

This is the best way to discourage players from cheesing their way to endgame gear. We were never supposed to be able to get whatever enchantments we want whenever we want them with just a few hours of easy grinding.

Enchantments are supposed to be rewards for actually playing the survival game like a survival game.

Now, I do understand that many players have come to see mending as a necessity, however, it is massively overpowered and discourages exploration and interaction with the rest of the game.

But I think we could mitigate the impact of mending finally being as rare as it should be by doing things like increasing the durability of weapons, and reducing the anvil penalty (but not removing it).

I think it adds a level of difficulty to getting those enchantments, I actually will not stuggle alot with this update as with the right level of enchantment table, a couple of the item to combine, and an anvil, you can hunt and add practically any enchantment. The only aspect I agree with is tridents since impaling 5 sucks to get and can't be acquired through villagers anymore.

I get that Mojang wants players to explore the world, but having certain enchanted book trades be limited to certain biomes isn’t the best way to do that. Making villager trading more frustrating than it already is will just make the game a worse experience for many.
senga ydal epud w ic juhc

there are definitely some ups and downs to this, the only thing im happy for is that a mending and unbreaking are guaranteed from the respective villagers now, but having them locked behind a biome sucks, like what if you are thousands of blocks away from a swamp, u just cant have mending or u need to make weird portals to get to the villager anytime u want the book.

I feel like they have a lot more things they can focus on right now instead of nerfing villagers, I literally don't understand the change at all unless they have some secret plan for 1.21 (extreme doubt though)

I feel like it’s implementation is a good idea but either anvils need a heafty rebalance or the master books need to be max level.

This would also be a great opportunity to buff enchanting tables as they have felt underwhelming ever since anvils have been introuduced. They need some way to give consistent-late game gear that isn’t just “enchant book put in anvil”
I would like it if this change could be deactivated by a gamerule

I'd like to see that villagers in certain biomes tend to sell one kind of enchantment more, but making enchantments biome specific and removing enchantments that you could buy now definitely feels like a downgrade in QoL

This Change is horrible and would honestly make me want to play the game less. I just learned the villager trading strategy’s and it now makes sense. I don’t think they need to be changed at all. All this will do is make villager trading more of a hassle and make me not even want to use them anymore. Please do not go through with this! Leave villagers as they are!

As someone who has played before villagers even had trades to begin with, I would hate to have items locked from players in more committed worlds. I love the landscapes of MC, but having to transport villagers thousands of blocks back to a base is tedious, and you already are going through all the trouble to get less expensive villager trades. That should be the hassle, not that atop transporting villagers. I agree that villagers have become essential to playing the game, especially after a hundred days in a single world, but I find myself needing to set up farms that already take hours in order for me to have enough supplies to build what I want. If this is the direction that the game goes in then I feel like the creativity aspect will be taken out entirely. Limiting the game to only farms, transporting things, and so many more unnecessary hours on projects that already take up hours on their own. In order to gather materials, I need enchantments, in order to get the enchants I need to build with said materials, I need to explore hundreds of thousands of blocks or I have to sit at an enchantment table all day with an anvil system that is barely function? Please do not make this change, or at the least make it a gamerule that can be turned on or off like another user had mentioned
Enchantments are supposed to be a challenge to obtain, at least not having librarians be as OP as they have been.

I totally agree with the idea of nerfing the discount sistem that comes with villager curing, it's clear that a stick shouldn't be worth as much as an emerald. However I find the differentiation of the trades to be excessive. I honestly feel that if you want us players to explore more you should give us a real prize, without making previously established mechanics progressively harder to pull off or use (netherite I'm looking at you). Moreover if players wanna play Minecraft using villagers breeders, why would you prevent them to do so? It's a sandbox game, you should be able to play it as you wish, almost by definition there isn't a wrong way. Following the same logic you should patch many others farms that make the game trivial, like mob grinders and iron farms (pls don't). 

If the game really feels too easy, which kinda does at this point, why not add more steps to the main quest instead? The game would vastly benefit from it.

Thanks for reading all of this nonsense.
Agreed! Since it's such a pain in the *** to transport villagers, its just so annoying to get swamp villagers to your base naturally... A new Idea is good but please not this.

This change sucks, I do NOT want to take villagers over 1800 blocks from my base just to get damned mending, this is a step backwards and nothing like the combat update, where the change just redid how you fight. This completely ruins bases that are far from swamps and superflat survival worlds by complicating or preventing entirely, the ability to get useful enchants.

Agree. Several folks have pointed out that Mending is SUPPOSED to be rare and so getting it renewably should be difficult enough that you would be more likely to only get Mending from loot, which, fair enough! But for multiplayer worlds, there kind of has to be a renewable option since that loot won't scale to be reasonable for a larger group of people -- so it matters if the renewable option is weird and unintuitive. The realm I play on isn't a bunch of professional youtubers who make trading halls as a matter of course... its just a bunch of friends who prettied up the closest village to trade with so we could all have access to enchantments, even the friends who joined late. I'm cool with making Mending more difficult or requiring more complex steps that take time, but villager moving is something so unintuitive that it doesn't feel like an intended part of the game. And after you've DONE that unintuitive step, it's not actually more difficult to acquire -- this doesn't really nerf things for the people who are willing to do that extra grind, it just makes it more annoying for them. Meanwhile the people who are just playing casual survival with friends are suddenly REQUIRED to do that unintuitive grind before they can have enough resources for everyone... this doesn't feel like the right way to accomplish the adjustments that people are hoping for.

I engirely agree, this change does nothing but make the mechanics far more annoying to engage with and a worse gameplay experience overall

there is no reason to do anything like this, and it removes such an immensely fun alternative path to progression, harming player freedom and agency and going against what Minecraft claims to stand for

this change cannot be implemented, it's horrible for the player

the trade_rebalance is simply stupid

and no way to manually turn off
It would be so incredible!

I was looking up how to structure my recipe file to allow me to use my custom items as ingredients but to my dismay that is not yet possible. I hope this is slated to be added soon. It would be amazing! Actually having custom crafting "tree" and not everything needing to be crafted from the vanilla resources would be so good for datapacks.

This would also allow the use of some currently unusable items for recipes. As of now you can't craft with Enchanted Books, Firework Rockets, Potions of any kind, Tipped Arrows, or any other vanilla items that require data.
I really hope this gets added relatively soon; it would make custom items entirely possible and functional without actually adding things!
It would be cool if mojang added this, I am currently working on a datapack with custom items, and if this was added the amount of stuff you could make would rival mods.
Mojang, PLEASE add this.
This is the single feature that datapacks are most in need of.
yes we need it.
More people should vote on this. It's a brilliant compromise.
I was just about to make a post with the exact same idea. Why does this have so few votes, it's the perfect solution to the current situation.
This is absolutely perfect and what I think the best choice is for the copper bulb

I personally feel as if this would be a more compromise-solution to the current issue of the usefulness!

As a casual redstoner (and (un)fortunately frequent modder) This feels like a more Mojang way to compromise and I love it!

Perfect compromise, this suggestion should receive far more attention.
Now, however, there's the issue that caused the nerf in the first place; this idea of Java edition needing to be brought in line with Bedrock ("parity") for......some reason?
To fix the fact that redstone on bedrock doesnt work on odd ticks mojang could just make the delays for bedrock even.
Yes, because it's too ennoying

These actions are also almost always accompanied with a datapack which

1. the player themselves installed, basically modding the game and requiring direct server access

2. can easily hide malicious commands within a function named whatever they want

3. can circumnavigate the whole point of the warning by using a custom trigger detected by the datapack to execute whatever is desired

All this succeeds in doing is hampering actual and earnest pack devs and players with a useless warning and no way of turning it off, at the very least please give us a checkbox or option to "Never show this again" for the warning for that world, namespace, or minecraft instance.

It's into June and I've been working on a written-book project with commands specifically designed to aid in larger creative projects, for several months now.  WHY are these warnings only showing up now and YES PLEASE, include some kind of option for us datapack makers to bypass it.
YES! This is actually annoying af.

YES. This prompt does not help at all and is just super annoying. /trigger is also annoying to set up and has severe problems. This should definitely be removed. Again, just like the chat censoring, this is not a "problem" YOU should mess with.

If the pop up only occurred for commands of permission level 3 and above (/kick, /ban, /op, /whitelist, etc.), this would actually make sense, since a level 2 op could hypothetically trick a level 3+ op into running a nefarious click event (level 2 has the means to create a click event with commands above their permission, 3+ has the means to run it). It makes little sense for typical level 2 commands.
Please give me a toggle for this. It's MY datapack on MY world that I HAVE WRITTEN. I do not need this prompt showing up every time I want to run a command that changes me to creative mode.
PLEASE REMOVE THIS ITS BREAKING MY MAPS

Since the introduction of the confirmation screen, it often does more harm than good — especially on servers or in adventure maps. It severely disrupts the gameplay experience and can even render some worlds unplayable. The confirmation message shows the entire command being executed, which may reveal sensitive or hidden technical functions to players who should not have access to them. These commands may fall under the intellectual property of the map creators. This opens the door to misuse and could even lead to unauthorized copying or exploitation.

I therefore urgently request that an option (e.g. a gamerule or setting) be added that allows administrators to disable or limit this confirmation screen where appropriate.

If an operator could create a supposedly harmful click event, then they have every means to just run a harmful command themselves. I really don't see how this prevents misuse. Ultimately, the problem lies on server administrators to manage their servers properly and for operators to use their power appropriately.
Pls remove this

I really understand the dangerous part about it. Someone could download a datapack which pretents to be a useful dialog based utility addition but then runs something like "/kill @e" or "/stop" in the background potentially breaking a lot of stuff in a world or maybe even a public server but wouldn't it be nice to add something like "/datapack trust [datapack-name]" so the operating users can decide themselves to disable additional security features for a specific datapack?

For run_command in the chat, inside books and any other text component this could be determined by a setting in the users Minecraft settings.

This is actually very annoying. As a passionate maker of story-driven adventure maps, this literally KILLED my drive for it. I have had more than 300 lines of dialogue written in 3 languages using the Tellraw command in command blocks (I know of the trigger command, but it is more difficult to use, and when there is so much dialogue, it takes a very long time to implement), and have a "skip" or "forward" button at each dilogue line for the player to take their time to read and advance as they need. This destroys the immersion and the frictionless design of my Minecraft maps - I try to make them as easy and hassle-free to set up and play as possible. I'd really appreciate a sort of toggle for this, preferably in the form of a gamerule.
Perhaps you should put this in the snapshot section so it can be noticed more.
esta buena la idea pero se podra aser seria muuuuuy dificil
you could add like zync and amber
you could add like zync and amber

Copper needs new recipes and this seems like a no brainer. I think it should have about 8 light level to differentiate from the regular lantern's 15 light level, and because there are no blocks in the game with 8 light level yet. I often feel like Soul Lanterns are too bright and Redstone Torches are too dim.
Perfect!

I agree that true copper blocks should keep their current recipe to keep their usability as a storage block.

I'd argue maybe cut copper should be even cheaper than that - This is meant to be a mid-game building material so I'd suggest 4 copper ingots for 2 cut copper blocks.
https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360074513072/comments/360013389431
https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360074513072/comments/360013389431
you can use a stonecutter to get it cheaper
why just cut copper? Tbh id rather build with the normal blocks.

I highly agree. I think the nerf from 4 ingots to 9 is totally unnecessary. It makes every individual block more expensive and equally more difficult to craft a decent output. Its like using iron blocks as building material. Though it looks good; its questionably expensive to be a building material. Not even end stone is that difficult to craft while it literally exists in a different dimension!

We can obtain huge amounts of copper by using a Fortune 3 pickaxe, and with the 1.18, we will find Copper veins, which are HUGE. Also, copper ore drops 1-3 raw copper on it's own, so the 9 crafting recipe is totally balanced

I have 4 enchantments in mind.
The first two are mutually exclusive, meaning you cannot have one or the other at the same time.
Packer I, II, III- increases capacity by a stack per level
Bundler I, II, III- allows you to place 1 unstackable item per level, in addition to your normal stacks
Scooper- Automatically puts dropped items into the bundle first
Surprise- Keeps bundle contents hidden, only shows how many different items are contained, but never what those are
enchantment: holding 1, 2, 3
YES YES YES, OR have like two different ones. Mutually exclusive like fortune or silk touch. One that expands the storage or something like that, and one that does what you say.
Well, yes, but actually no... Maybe stacking only up to 8 or 4?
It'd also be good to just be able to take select items out of a bundle instead of having to empty them each time to get the one item you want.
64 should be the stack limit for bundles. Remember this isn't stacking bundles that have things in them or stacking bundles inside of bundles.
Maybe a stack of sixteen. It would work the way buckets stack.
Absolutely. Would make perfect sense, since buckets and bottles already work the same way. Stackable when empty, not when filled. Could even be applied to Shulker boxes. Consistent Minecraft logic!
I agree.  Since a bundle consumes 4/64 spaces when nested within another bundle, empty bundles should stack to 16.
A deep sea that went further underground would be amazing
Short of adding a whole deep dark ocean biome, just make the floor of the deep ocean biomes around 0, instead of 45 where it is now.
Wow

Yes! Oceans never feel deep and mysterious because you can almost always see the bottom (I play on super dark settings because I love horror games and hate fun) maybe that's not a problem for most people. We definitely need some form of hostile or at least defensive mobs for these deep-sea areas I think. In any case, more volume to explore can only do good in a sandbox game about exploration!
It would be cool if you could destroy this block using arrows from afar
That literally makes sense, I would not be the player who would throw a bee hive/nest into lava but those who do should be surprised with angry bees.
I think if you throw a beehive at anything it should break and angry bees should attack any nearby players, mobs and animals.
No! Its a great idea but its a literal lag machine! A signle bundle filled with bee hives would be enough to crash the game!
this is the smartest thing i've heard today

Whoever said anything about the lag, it doesn't even have to be in a bundle. you could just throw a stack of bee hives and it would cause lots of lag. But causing lag in Minecraft is very easy, and this feature should be implemented anyways. It would take a while to find and silk touch 64 bee hives.
Very interesting

I think the ritual should include the blowing of the goat horn. This will open up the portal, but at the same time will sound off all the shriekers in the area. This is both incredible and terrifying and you will likely have 15-20 wardens chasing after you as you run towards the open portal

The fact that reinforced deep-slate remains moveable as of now is spectacular as it preforms the actions of bedrock in a survival friendly fashion. It seems perfect that in order to obtain such a rare block to implement into a wither cage, etc, one would need to fly it via slime-stone all the way to a base or farming area. Personally, I do feel that Minecraft has enough dimensions (especially for the casual player), and adding another method of “teleportation” is not needed whatsoever as ender pearls are more than enough. The warden like structure in the center of ancient cities is an amazing view to say the least and I do believe that it should not serve further function besides collecting or carting off the center deep-slate pieces. The main argument for the center blocks to be moveable is that they add not only a new aspect of challenge to the game, but also provide a plethora of technical, interesting uses. If they are to be moveable, then they should most definitely not be portal blocks as portal frames haven’t been moveable throughout Minecraft’s history. To conclude, the implementation of ancient cities and the “deep dark” has been amazing, but the center warden statue should not be a portal and should be transportable. This is simply the opinion of one technical and embellishment loving Minecraft enthusiast.
Once you enter the portal it should be made of some kind of sculk.
minecraft needs this feature, it should be in 1.20!
I'm waiting to see the ancient portal
Why don't we make a sculk dimension. We've already seen it in plenty of clickbait videos.
Why does this not have a ton of votes? This is way more important than any feature, bug-fix or parody issue!

Every community is different, and Mojang doesn't seem to understand that. Decentralized 3rd party servers are what makes Minecraft what it is today. By adding centralized moderation, you're going to ruin communities of people. Servers will be required to disable online-mode just so they can have their own set of rules, not enforced by Mojang's community policies.

You're killing the game :(

Centralized moderation would absolutely kill private servers and LAN servers, which should in no way be controlled by anyone but the players on those servers.

Either have centralized moderation be an optional features that server owners can opt into (NOT opt out of) or don't add it at all.
How did you predict this a year ago?
I agree

Dude, it is a good idea but devs said in QnA that they do not care about our wishes, and this feature will be automatically active for all servers without the possibility of disabling. Plugins can help you, there is one that disables that feauture.

Or just get rid of it because no one asked for it and no one wants it, and everyone is against it..

Microsoft doesn't listen to the community, and I'm not playing past 1.19
This is an amazing idea. I hope it is seen!
I really like this Idea.

Love the Idea of Water freezing in snowy biomes, imagine finding a big lake on a server and going all "ouiiii" with your friends. Overall it will make as you say the game more diverse, great idea mate thanks for sharing it!

It would also be interesting to find biome specific variants of hostile mobs in different biomes in caves. For example, in a mesa, there could be miner zombies that act like husks and give you mining fatigue (also applicable for abandoned mineshafts), or frost spiders that are the same size as cave spiders but apply slowness, or geode creepers that have to be attacked with a pickaxe and drop amethyst shards that only spawn near amethyst geode structures. 

As we already have variants of mobs like the stray and husk, this seems feasible without much work, and would add much needed variation and differences to biome, especially underground.

I think that the underground of diferent biomes should be really different

Not the entire underground of course. The original cave "biome" should still exist no matter what is the biome it is in. But the underground should have huge differences by biome like Terraria does. Different blocks, generation, mobs etc.

I'm glad that so many of you like my idea!

There is, of course, the problem of how drastic these biome-specific features would be. For example, how much sandstone exactly would there be in desert biomes? Would it cover about as much of the cave walls as andesite? Or more? Or even less?

The idea True Inf3rno gave is an interesting one too. I'm not sure about adding new mobs, but if husks/strays spawned underground occasionally it might be a fun twist.

And don't forget to mention other ideas for biome-specific features, I've only thought of 4, and would be curious to see what you can think of.

Here are 4 more ideas:

Patches of gravel generating in mountains biomes. These could generate only on the floor, but it might be fun to have them in the ceiling.

Patches of podzol and mossy boulders generating on the floor in giant tree taiga biomes.

Patches of mycelium and small mushrooms generating on the floor in mushroom island biomes.

Patches of dirt generating in swamp biomes.

What do you think of those ideas?

I'm in love with this idea. Some more:

Icicles (columns of 2+ ice blocks) on cave ceilings in snowy biomes

Buried ruins of villages in village biomes

Blobs of dead coral blocks in warm oceans

Or maybe twist it and have dead corals in, say, mesas, to show that what's a dry cliffscape now was once a lush ocean floor, just like irl. Would lend credibility to the idea of archeology in Minecraft.

There could maybe be much more lava and even magma in hotter climates! There's a lot of potential here for biome-cave similarities that don't really even need to be different cave biomes but rather just specific enhancements. The tree on the surface leading to the lush caves is a good example of how this could be done.

the cave biome would be a biomes sub biome

examples

jungle caves

flower forest caves

this would apply to all biome variations if they added something new
Sure! And the cobblestone version could generate in a certain biome

I agree the current natural stone looks like a bunch of bricks almost, it should be smoother when it naturally generates. The name "Grimstone" also sounds weird, sounds like a 12 year old came up with it (no offense)

I agree with this idea.

Giving Grimstone a more smooth and natural looking texture would make it fit the caves better, and using the current texture for Grim Cobblestone would make a lot of sense and keep the builders happy.
absolutely! i love the blocks but if they worked in the same was as stone and when you mined them youd get cobbled grimstone

It would be a shame to lose the current texture for grimstone. I really do love its look in building, and it has a lot of potential in that sector. While it personally doesn't work in a cave during high light circumstances, having it as the texture for its cobble variant is brilliant! You get the best of both worlds that way!

I agree. I love the texture of Deepslate as a building block but it's far too busy for a stone replacement. I think the addition of cobbled deepslate indicates an upcoming retexture for regular deepslate, as they currently look very similar. I would love for the regular block to keep a similar dark, sedimentary look, but it currently looks more like blackstone bricks. If the different texture colors were more similar, that would definitely help.

I agree 100% The default Deepslate looks too much like bricks - the naturally generated caves look like they are made of bricks because of it. I'd LOVE to see smooth Deepslate have the top and bottom textures on all sides, and when mined they turn to cobbled Deepslate, like Stone!
Is there a deepslate analogue of smooth stone yet? Make that smooth on all sides

I think the Deepslate should be smoother, yeah. Even with the current retexture it doesn't look right. I think it should be closer to regular stone in surface texture. Not completely, but still smoother. It looks a titchbit busy. Maybe just making it like Netherrack, where the texture is there but the contrast isnt as bad.

I also think that it should be a bit lighter. Either that or you should be able to make building stuff out of Tuff, because as of the current snapshot the gradient between cobble and Deepslate is still too rough.

Versión 2.21.7

As a server admin, I find this drastically needed. Without digging into details or keeping up with the news, 1.21.9 looks no different to me than 1.21.10 and doesn’t help me understand the purpose of the new version. Is it just bugfixes? Is it a content update? A good version numbering system would help me understand at a glance.

While the actual system used for numbering doesn’t matter much to me, having something that distinguishes drop updates from hot and bug fix releases would be really useful, especially for server and mod maintenance.
